user_query: Which are the classes of anti-arrhythmic drugs according to Vaughan-Williams classification?
text-davinci-002_response: There are four classes of anti-arrhythmic drugs according to Vaughan-Williams classification: class I, class II, class III, and class IV. Class I anti-arrhythmic drugs work by slowing down the electrical conduction in the heart. This slows the heart rate and prevents irregular heartbeats. Class II anti-arrhythmic drugs work by blocking the electrical signal that causes the heart to beat too fast. Class III anti-arrhythmic drugs work by lengthening the time it takes for the electrical signal to travel through the heart. This slows the heart rate and prevents irregular heartbeats. Class IV anti-arrhythmic drugs work by blocking the electrical signal that causes the heart to beat too fast.

user_query: Explain the concept proteostasis.
text-davinci-002_response:
Proteostasis is the collection of processes that a cell uses to maintain the proper folding and function of its proteins. Proteins are the largest and most complex molecules in cells, and they perform many vital functions. In order for a protein to function properly, it must first be correctly folded into its three-dimensional structure. This process is often assisted by other proteins, called chaperones.
Misfolded proteins can cause a number of problems for cells, including disrupting the function of other proteins, accumulating inside cells and eventually leading to cell death. To prevent these problems, cells have developed a number of mechanisms to keep their proteins correctly folded. These mechanisms make up the proteostasis network.

user_query: What is SHAPE-Seq?
text-davinci-002_response:
SHAPE-Seq is a method for determining the three-dimensional structure of RNA molecules. It is based on the principle of sequencing the nucleotides in an RNA molecule and then using that information to generate a three-dimensional model of the molecule.
The first step in SHAPE-Seq is to sequence the RNA molecules of interest. This can be done using any of a number of sequencing methods, such as next-generation sequencing. Once the RNA molecules have been sequenced, the data are used to generate a three-dimensional model of the molecule.
SHAPE-Seq has a number of advantages over other methods for determining the three-dimensional structure of RNA molecules. One advantage is that it does not require the use of expensive equipment or facilities. Another advantage is that it can be used to study RNA molecules that are difficult or impossible to study using other methods.

text-davinci-002_response:
Diego MartÃ­n Vaccari, PhD, from the Department of Virology at the University of La Plata, Argentina, answers:
Many arboviruses are transmitted by arthropods, especially mosquitoes and ticks. In general, virions are injected by the vector into the vertebrate host during blood feeding. user_query: Which effects create neighborhoods of transcriptional regulation in eukaryotes?
text-davinci-002_response: One effect that creates neighborhoods of transcriptional regulation in eukaryotes is the presence of nuclear pores. Nuclear pores act as selective pores in the nuclear envelope, allowing small molecules to pass in and out of the nucleus while preventing the escape of larger molecules. The nuclear pore plays a role in transcriptional regulation by keeping transcription factors in the nucleus, where they can interact with DNA. Another effect that creates neighborhoods of transcriptional regulation in eukaryotes is the presence of chromatin. Chromatin is a complex of DNA and proteins that helps to package DNA into a more compact form and helps to control which genes are transcribed. Chromatin can be organized into different structures, such as heterochromatin and euchromatin, which have different effects on transcriptional regulation. Heterochromatin is generally more compact and is less likely to be transcribed, while euchromatin is more open and is more likely to be transcribed.

user_query: In which fields of DNA sequencing are Bloom filters applied?

It includes any method or technology that is used to determine the order of the four basesâadenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymineâin a stretch of DNA. The field of DNA sequencing has seen a number of important developments over the past few decades.
One area in which Bloom filters have been applied is in the assembly of genomes from next-generation sequencing data. Genome assembly is the process of putting together the sequence of nucleotides that make up an organism's genome. Next-generation sequencing technologies produce large amounts of data that need to be processed and assembled into a finished genome.
Bloom filters can be used to quickly identify which sequence reads are likely to be part of the same genome. This can speed up the assembly process and improve the accuracy of the final genome.
Another area in which Bloom filters have been applied is in the analysis of DNA methylation. Methylation is a process by which a methyl group is added to a DNA molecule. This can alter the function of the DNA and is thought to be involved in a variety of biological processes.

user_query: Describe GARLIC (GWAS-based Prediction Toolkit for Connecting Diseases and Cell Types)
text-davinci-002_response: GARLIC is a computational toolkit that uses whole-genome association studies (GWAS) to predict disease-associated cell types. GWAS are a powerful means of identifying genetic risk factors for complex diseases, but the cell types in which disease-associated variants act are often unknown. GARLIC uses a robust statistical approach to identify the cell types most likely to be involved in disease pathogenesis from GWAS data. This approach is based on the premise that if a disease-associated variant is active in a given cell type, then that cell type is likely to be enriched for genes whose expression is altered in the disease. GARLIC has been used to predict cell-type-specific gene regulatory networks for a variety of diseases, including Alzheimer's disease, diabetes, and rheumatoid arthritis.

user_query: Describe the 4D-CHAINS algorithm
text-davinci-002_response: The 4D-CHAINS algorithm is an efficient method for solving the protein structure determination problem that has been demonstrated to be effective for proteins of up to medium size. The algorithm is based on the observation that the 3D folds of proteins are composed of a small number of repeating building blocks, or domains, that are arranged in a specific order. The 4D-CHAINS algorithm exploit this structural regularity by first breaking the protein down into its constituent domains, and then solving for the 3D structure of each domain independently. Once the structures of the domains have been determined, the 4D-CHAINS algorithm uses a combinatorial search procedure to identify the protein's overall 3D fold by determining the optimal combination of domain structures that best fits the known protein sequence.

user_query: What is CVT-301?
text-davinci-002_response:
CVT-301 is a Phase III clinical trial evaluating the use of vasostasin, an antibody drug conjugate (ADC), in patients with metastatic triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). The trial is being conducted by Celldex Therapeutics, Inc.
The primary objective of CVT-301 is to determine the overall response rate (ORR) of vasostasin in patients with metastatic TNBC. Secondary objectives include evaluation of progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), and safety of vasostasin.
Enrollment in the trial began in September 2016, and it is currently ongoing. The trial is expected to be completed in May 2019.
CVT-301 is a multicenter, open-label, single-arm trial. A total of 120 patients will be enrolled in the trial, and will receive vasostasin at a dose of 10 mg/kg every 3 weeks. Patients will be followed for a minimum of 24 weeks.
The ORR is the primary endpoint of the trial, and will be measured by RECIST v1.1. Secondary endpoint measures include PFS, OS, and safety of vasostasin.
As of September 2018, results from the trial have not yet been reported.

user_query: What is the cause of a STAG3 truncating variant?
text-davinci-002_response: A mutation in the STAG3 gene is the cause of a STAG3 truncating variant. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called cohesin-3. This protein is a component of the cohesin complex, which is required for the proper separation of replicated chromosomes during cell division. Mutations in the STAG3 gene lead to a shortened, nonfunctional form of the cohesin-3 protein. As a result, the cohesin complex is not as effective at separating chromosomes, which leads to the accumulation of chromosomal abnormalities. These changes in chromosome number and structure are responsible for the signs and symptoms of Cornelia de Lange syndrome, a condition that is characterized by growth delays, intellectual disability, and distinctive facial features.

user_query: What is epitranscriptomics?
text-davinci-002_response:
Epitranscriptomics is the study of RNA modifications, particularly those that affect gene expression. These modifications can include changes to the base sequence of RNA, modifications to the RNA's sugar-phosphate backbone, or addition of chemical groups to the RNA's bases. Many of these modifications are catalyzed by enzymes called RNA modifying enzymes (RMEs).
Epitranscriptomic modifications can affect gene expression in a number of ways. For example, they can influence the stability of RNA, the way RNA is processed, or how RNA interacts with proteins. In addition, epitranscriptomic modifications can be involved in regulating alternative splicing, a process whereby a single gene can give rise to multiple different proteins.
RMEs are found in all three domains of life, and the specific modifications they catalyze vary depending on the organism. For example, in humans, one type of RME called an RNA methyltransferase is responsible for adding a methyl group to a specific RNA base, a modification that affects the way that RNA is processed.
Despite their importance, epitranscriptomic modifications are still not well understood. In particular, it is not known how widespread these modifications are, what role they play in gene expression, or how they are regulated. elucidating the role of epitranscriptomic modifications in gene expression will provide insights into a wide range of biological processes, including development, metabolism, and disease.

user_query: What is known about autosomal dominant Alzheimerâs disease?
text-davinci-002_response:
There are several types of Alzheimerâs disease, and autosomal dominant Alzheimerâs disease (ADAD) is one of them. This form of Alzheimerâs disease is caused by a mutation in the gene that codes for amyloid precursor protein (APP). This protein is involved in the formation of amyloid plaques, which are a hallmark of Alzheimerâs disease. The mutated gene causes increased production of APP, which leads to the formation of more amyloid plaques.
ADAD usually affects people in their 30s, 40s, or 50s, and it tends to run in families. However, not everyone who inherits the mutated gene will develop the disease. People with ADAD often experience a gradual decline in cognitive abilities, and they may eventually need help with activities of daily living. There is no cure for ADAD, and there is no treatment that can stop or reverse the progression of the disease.

user_query: List the stages/types of Multiple Sclerosis.
text-davinci-002_response:
There are four main types of Multiple Sclerosis:
1. Relapsing-remitting MS: This is the most common type of MS, characterized by periods of symptom flare-ups (relapses) followed by periods of remission, during which symptoms improve or disappear entirely.
2. Secondary-progressive MS: This type of MS typically begins as relapsing-remitting MS, but eventually transitions to a more progressive disease course marked by a gradual worsening of symptoms.
3. Primary-progressive MS: This rarer form of MS is characterized by a gradual worsening of symptoms from the beginning, with no periods of remission.
4. Progressive-relapsing MS: This rarest form of MS is characterized by a gradual worsening of symptoms from the beginning, interspersed with intermittent relapses.

user_query: What is endoplasmic reticulum stress?
text-davinci-002_response: Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress is a condition in which the normal function of the ER is disrupted. The ER is a type of organelle found in eukaryotic cells, which is responsible for many important cellular functions, including the synthesis of proteins. When the ER is stressed, these functions are impaired, and the cell is unable to properly synthesize proteins. This can lead to the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the ER, which can further increase the stress on the organelle and cause the cell to die.

user_query: What is RADICL-seq?
text-davinci-002_response:
RADICL-seq shines light on the dark matter of the transcriptome. RNA transcripts are notoriously difficult to detect and quantify due to their low abundance and small size. RADICL-seq is a method that uses light to label and capture RNA transcripts with high specificity and sensitivity. This method was developed by Dr. Coletrap and her team at the University of California, Berkeley.
RADICL-seq begins with the identification of RNA transcripts of interest. These transcripts are then labeled with a photoactivatable RNA-binding protein (PARP). PARP is a protein that binds to RNA and is activated by light. Once activated, PARP will label the RNA transcript with a fluorescent marker.
Next, the labeled RNA transcripts are captured on a solid support, such as a glass slide or metal plate. The support is then exposed to light, which activates PARP and causes it to bind to the RNA transcripts. After binding, the RNA transcripts are cleaved by PARP and released from the support.
Lastly, the released RNA transcripts are quantified using real-time PCR or next-generation sequencing. This allows for the detection and quantification of RNA transcripts that would otherwise be undetectable.
RADICL-seq is a powerful tool for the study of RNA transcripts. This method can be used to detect and quantify RNA transcripts that are difficult to detect by other methods. In addition, RADICL-seq can be used to study the structure and function of RNA transcripts.

user_query: what about semmelweis and medicine 's shameful handwashing history ?
text-davinci-002_response: In 1847, Ignaz Semmelweis, a Hungarian doctor working in Vienna, realized that the high rate of death from childbed fever (then also known as puerperal fever) in his hospital was due to doctors and medical students not washing their hands after autopsy work in the morgue. He introduced a strict handwashing policy and the rate of death from childbed fever dropped dramatically. However, his findings were not accepted by the medical establishment of his day and he was eventually forced to leave his position. It was not until the work of British doctor Joseph Lister in the 1860s that the importance of cleanliness in medicine was widely accepted.
